The good news is that resistances aren't forever.
Producing betalactamases or other cephalosporinases is energy consuming. So provided we stop the environnemental pressure (using said antibiotic), the gene becomes a hindrance and in a few generations the resistance disapears.

It is already used in many hospitals were we face multiresistant bacterias. The infectiologues team keeps rotating the different antibiotics families so as to give time for the bacterias to lose some of the resistance. It implies to use some old antibiotics which were dropped at some point because they had more side effect, but it is a working strategy.

We are currently using it at the pitié Salpetriere hospital and it works well, as long as we have a team overseeing the use of antibiotics and a sharp follow of the bacterial population and its resistances.

As someone who works in the field, I can say that unfortunately new antibiotics trials are both too expensive and less rewarding, in terms of cash, than drugs against diseases that can't be cured completelly. Just wrap your head around this: in the past 40 years there's been only one antibiotic that was approved for medical use against tuberculosis, and the rest of the anti-tuberculosis drugs would not be approved by FDA if they were discovered today, meaning, while plenty of new antibiotics are being discovered annually, FDA forbids their use on the pretext of the adverse effects they pose. While at the same time the longer they're no new antibiotics on the market, the more the bacteria have a chance to adapt to the drugs that are ancient but still in use and aquire resistance against them. The future is really expected to be full of superbugs in a decade or two.

How to make homemade, natural antibiotics

Make your own natural antibiotic
Natural antibiotics with honey and turmeric are known in many cultures as "golden honey", and it is a natural cure for your health thanks to the ability to destroy bacteria and viruses.

Many have added it to their daily diet as a method to strengthen their immune system. But it also works as a treatment for existing infections.

Remember that it is important to do the treatment with the highest quality ingredients as it only then has the best benefits.

What you need
4 tablespoons organic honey
1 1/2 tablespoon ground turmeric
1 glass jar with lid
1 small wooden spoon
preparation
First pour the honey into a glass jar and add the turmeric.
Stir with the wooden spoon.
Cover the jar tightly and leave overnight.
Use
Take a spoon every day, preferably on an empty stomach.
To make the mixture easier to absorb, you can mix the spoon in a little warm water.
If you have an infection, try taking the cure up to three times a day.

Contraindications
Patients with gallstones or liver disease should not use natural antibiotics of this kind.

The last lines, where they said "there is research for new antibiotics" is relatively overplayed in this video as there is truly limited, if any, R&D for new antibiotics. This is because of a few reasons:
1. Development for drugs takes many decades, especially for an antibiotic, as we must find a broad spectrum (which are relatively hard) to match the current antibiotics today. - Tbh, my opinion here.
2. For many years, we did not do any research, as companies did not realise the gravity of antibiotic resistance. They basically thought this is the end of bacterial infections. And did not invest in further research.
3. Even when companies do invest in research now, the drug soon becomes futile due to resistance (decades of research and money vs 5 yrs on the market). The company cannot even get the cash it invested back after its on the market. Basically, it's just not profitable.

Antibiotics are, again, in my opinion, an old technology that is not specialised enough. As my lecturer for microbiomes said, "It's like killing an ant with a hammer." From what I learn, (which honestly isn't much) bacteriophages and synthetic biology sound to be the best bet against bacterial infections.

I know nobody is gonna even see this comment, but I gotta say this because I'm tired of seeing all these self-righteous pricks in the comments:

When he said that "A cheeseburger has to cost a dollar" at 3:54, that wasn't just some snide jab at fast food. For food to be accessible, it needs to be cheap to make. Antibiotics in agriculture is a serious problem, not just for all the reasons in the video, but because if we just stopped using them altogether, then the cost of producing food would skyrocket. It's really easy to accuse agribusiness as being abusive of antibiotics in their endless quest for greed and money, or some other pseudo-intellectual bullshit like that, and demand that governments do something to stop them from using antibiotics. But when you do that, you're not really hurting those businessmen. In all likelihood, the only people you're hurting are the global poor.

Oh, and to the vegans who will inevitably reply to my comment if they read it: plant agriculture uses antibiotics too. There are plenty of good, valid reasons to embrace veganism; this isn't one of them.

Antibiotics are a fascinating and important tool that should be used carefully. That said, evolving antibiotic resistance cost energy upkeep for a bacteria, so in a situation without antibiotics they lose the trait in favour of more energy. The best solution for minimising resistance is to use apropriately and cycle through antibiotics so the bacteria are constantly chasing the curve. There should still be a nuclear option antibiotic though, as some bacteria just have natural unadapted resistance due to structure.

Basically, we only call them "super bugs" because they are immune to current antibiotics, but the truth is that they are just normal diseases. They are resistant to some things, but vulnerable to others. There will never be a bug that is resistant to everything because there is only so much energy that can be dedicated to defending itself from antibiotics before it has to stop doing what makes it a problem in the first place. So it will become resistant to current antibiotics and science will develop some new ones to counter it either until the bug is fully wiped out or until humanity runs out of resources to do so. Or for eternity considering we can never be sure that we've completely wiped out something so small and we'll probably continue to gather resources from space one day.

Evolution is give and take. In order to gain advantage in one area, energy must be given over to that and thus advantage in a different area must be lost. The only way to avoid this is to increase energy intake which in itself also causes problems in other ways, but many species, like bacteria, are too far into nitch categories to be able to really do this. The problem area for us is that they might reproduce so quickly that we simply can't keep up with the changes.

Still, I'm no biologist, so this is just my laymen understanding of it. Feel free to correct me if you like.

This video uses the term "immunity" incorrectly.  Immunity refers to the immune system.  Since bacteria don't have an immune system, they can't have immunity.  The word that the video meant was "resistance," which refers to the acquisition of some trait that protects it against a specific antibiotic.

Well, bacteria develops resistance to antibiotics, we make more antibiotics, and, eventually, those ones become obsolete. Seems like we're climbing an endless ladder. Might as well play Snake Eater.

Thinking about it, one ideal solution is circular - when antibiotic A begins to fail, switch to B, when B begins to fail, switch to C, and by the time C begins to fail, A will work again. The premise is that when natural selection favors those entities that can resist the new antibiotic, by the time they get to C, resistance to A will have been lost.

I've also heard that new antibiotics haven't been developed since the early 1970's due to it being unprofitable. If this is the case, then this is a good example of where government needs to step in - to contribute to where a beneficial pursuit is not profitable (either by financing it or by developing it itself, and the former seems like the better way to go).

What the bacteria isn't counting with is that evolution works both sides. If they start killing a lot of humans, they'll start selecting those humans that have stronger immunological systems, thus creating super bacteria-resistant humans.

"Antiobotics should be a last-resort drug, not something you take because your cold is annoying."  I think it's more appropriate to say that antiobotics should be taken sparingly and chosen with care to fight specific bacterial infections.  Colds are not caused by bacterial infections, and antibiotics are ineffective against them."  Antibiotics used as a last resort is not appropriate.  For instance, a 7-year-old boy in Italy recently died from otitis media - a simple ear infection - because he was treated with homeopathic medicine.  Antibiotics were used as a last resort when the infection had already progressed too much.  Larger numbers of bacteria increase the chances of random antibiotic-resistant mutants...which is exactly what we do not want.

Another point not talked about in the video but is equally critical is Hygiene and cleaning products. Hand soaps do not need antibacterial ingredients since most Hand washing removed enough germs and dirt. If more germs need to be killed then rubbing alcohol works just as well yet is safer since it doesn't cause any antibiotic resistance. Cleaning products also should not contain drugs inside (like Lysol) because normal cleaning will remove a safe amount of pathogens. When more hygiene is needed then using hydrogen Peroxide, Alcohol, or very rarely, bleach will remove the bacteria.

What would you say if we told you that humanity is currently making a collaborative effort to engineer the perfect superbug? A bug that could kill hundreds of millions of people? Well, it is happening right now>. We are in the process of creating a super bacterium.
Bacteria are among the oldest living things on this planet. The smallest thing we still consider life, they are masters of survival and can be found everywhere. Most bacteria are harmless to us. Your body hosts trillions of them, and they help you to survive. But others can invade your body, spread quickly, and kill you.
Millions of people used to die as result of bacterial infections. Until we developed a superweapon- antibiotics. Together with vaccinations, antibiotics revolutionized medicine and saved millions of lives.
Antibiotics kill the vast majority of susceptible bacteria fairly quickly, leaving only a small group of survivors that our immune system then deals with easily. How do antibiotics do this? Imagine a bacterium as a very complex machine with thousands of complex processes going on that keep it alive and active. Antibiotics disrupt this complex machinery, for example, by interfering with its metabolism, slowing down their growth significantly, so they are less of a threat. Other antibiotics attack DNA and prevent it from being replicated, which stops bacteria from multiplying, ultimately killing them. Or by simply ripping the outer layer of bacteria to shreds, so that their insides spill out and they die quickly. All of this without bothering body cells. But now, evolution is making things more complicated. By pure random chance, a small minority of the bacteria invading your body might have evolved a way to protect themselves. For example, by intercepting the antibiotics and changing the molecule so it becomes harmless. Or by investing energy in pumps that eject the antibiotics before they can do damage. A few immune bacteria are not that big of a deal, because the immune system can take care of them. But if they escape, they might spread their immunity.
How can bacteria spread immunity? First of all, bacteria have two kinds of DNA: the chromosome and small free-floating parts called plasmids, meaning they can hug each other and exchange those plasmids to exchange useful abilities. This way, immunity can be spread quickly through a population. Or, in a process called transformation, bacteria can harvest dead bacteria and collect DNA pieces. This even works between different bacteria species and can lead to superbugs, bacteria that are immune to multiple antibiotics.
A variety of superbugs already exist in the world. Especially hospitals are the perfect breeding ground for them. Humans have short memories. The horros of the pre-antibiotic era have been forgotten. Today, we treat this powerful medicine as a commodity instead of as the game-changing achievement of science that it is. This has led to a strange disconnect: hundreds of millions of people still don’t have access to antibiotics in developing countries, while in other parts of the world antibiotics are prescribed too freely and taken without care. Antibiotic should be a last-resort drug, not something you take because your cold is annoying. Antoher serious problem is antibiotic use in meat production. At any particular point in time, humanity holds between 20 and 30 billion animal as livestock. To make meat cheaper, many animals are held in horrible conditions, in very tight spaces, and in unhygienic conditions, the perfect breeding ground for disease. So many animals are given antibiotics to kill as many bacteria as possible and prevnt them from getting sick. Because a cheeseburger has to cost a dollar. Unsurprisingly, as a result of this system, we have created more and more bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics. To counteract this, we use a different antibiotics and we have another secret weapon: there are specific antibiotics that are used to wipe out bacteria that have developed resistance. There are stict rules for using these to avoid the creation of a superbacterium or so we thought. In late 2015, scary news arrived from china, resistance against colistin, a last-ditch antibiotic, had been discovered. Colistin is an old drug and was rarely used, because it can damage the liver. So there was little resistance against it, which made it a great antibiotic of last resort for certain complex infections that occur in hospitals to fight bacteria that have become immune to a whole bunch of other drugs. So this mean bacteria resistance to colistin is very, very bad news. It might destroy a last line of defense and lead to a whole lot of dead people.
How could this happen? Millions of animals in Chinese pig farms have been given colistin for years. Resistant bacteria developed, spreading first from animal to animal, and then to human without being noticed. On a average day, there are over 100,000 flights on earth, kind of connecting every human on the planet. By creating the modern world, we have also built the infrastructure for a dangerous pandemic.
Still, we don’t need to panic just yet. Bacteria evolve, humans do research, new antibiotics are developed as old ones become obsolete, technology is advancing every day. The problem is real and serious but the fight is far from over. If humanity plays its cards right, superbugs might turn out to be not very super after all.

The ending is giving false hope however. The unfortunate reality is that we are losing. A new antibiotic was released just a few years ago to treat a strain of multi-drug resistance P. auriginosa, and now 2 years later it is already immune.
The drug companies have to jump through hoops to get these drugs approved by the FDA, it takes time and money before they can begin making back the money they spent in the antibiotic's initial creation. But since the bug it was designed to treat is already resistant, the drug is now useless and they will not sell more of it.

The result is that these scientists have been getting out of the antibiotic's business for more profitable venues. Which means the amount of people continuing to fight this war is continuing to drop. less and less antibiotcs are being produced farther and farther apart from each other.

Eventually we will lose and all of humanity will perish.

The ending seems very comforting and all, until you figure out how long the drug making process is. First the researcher must decide what he is going to make. Get the money. Research and try to make a small sample of the product. Then he must find willing and healthy test subjects. If there is little and non-harmful symptoms then he may get permission to try the product on actual sick subjects. If the product actually works, then he must find out how to distribute his product to over thousands of people, how is he going to make this product into giant quantities? For this he will need EVEN MORE MONEY. By the end of this, he is a debt and must pay off this debt by selling his life-saving product everywhere for expensive amounts. This entire process takes a span of 7-10 years (or longer) and if any of these steps fail, he will have to start back over. By this time, many superbugs may have formed and kill many people. Plus, moving to Greenland won't solve your problems.

So what would stop an evil scientist with access to various antibiotics, a set of nutrient agar petri dishes, access to common bacteria that are normally infectious to humans, access to bacteria commonly found in farm animals which would be especially harmful to humans, and a few simple household mutagens from going through the motions of intentionally creating a super bug resistant to every single antibiotic in existence? I mean, aside from the fact that the person doing the research would die making it without proper protection and still would likely die if it got into the wild.

On the bright side, CRISPR is being used to created modified T-cells - some of which to target cancer cells, but I read a bit about people looking into it's use as an antibiotic. Even in the total absence of usable antibiotics, if we can create T-cells that fight every virus or bacteria that shouldn't be an issue.

Then again, an evil scientist trying to doom the world with a super plague could use that process to modify their own T cells to make themselves immune, and if the plague is fast enough it would pretty much wipe out the majority of humanity before someone else could isolate it and create a cure assuming anyone does so at all. Of course, that would be a little more specialized than the few hundred dollars it would take to create something that would also kill the scientist.

Humans have used biological warfare even before humans had the ability to make things like that, so it's not an unrealistic scenario. Humans even decided to bring a plague back to life after exterminating it's entire species, and you can actually download viral or bacterial DNA from such plagues, have a lap build it for you, and mail it to a residential address. People have done that already. So how long before one person randomly decides to doom the entire world?

So just adding my two cents here....

Bacteria can only hold so much information at once. Becoming resistant to one drug may well require giving up resistance to another. We see something similar to this in some forms of vaccine development: a disease which thrives in the human body is injected into an unfamiliar environment (perhaps, say, a chicken egg), where it must now adapt in order to survive. In doing so, it loses some of its ability to thrive in the human body. If it loses enough to where it won't be able to out-adapt the human immune system, it can now serve as a viable vaccine.

This sort of sentiment is probably what they mean when they say "if humanity plays its cards right." Overall, good, informative video.

This is a very good video, but also want to point out that antibiotics ARE NOT like taking cough syrup.  They have a battery of side effects that kill and/or permanently disable people.  Metronidazole (aka Flagyl) can act like a neurotoxin in the brain; fluoroquinolone antibiotics, like Levaquin and Cipro, can damage the brain and all the tendons in the body due to the fact they attack mitrochondial DNA (that's the stuff that gives you energy) the same way they destroy bad bacteria.   In other words, demanding your doctor give you an antibiotic "just in case" your cold isn't a cold, is a BAD IDEA.

We have other weapons too, that we're....reluctant to use. A last resort in case antibiotics fail. Research is being heavily done on bacteriophage viruses - viruses that infect bacteria. Should antibiotics fail catastrophically and a very bad strain of bacteria show up, we could engineer a virus that would attack those bacteria. And then we could infect large numbers of humans with it. Its worth noting that there has never been an instance of a bacteriophage virus evolving to the point where it infected anything other than bacteria in the billions of years viruses have existed. But I'm sure i don't need to explain why we are reluctant to attempt this, even knowing the risks are minimal.

Ehhhh that was a heavy dose of false hope at the end. When it comes to discovering new antibiotics we have exhaustively picked all of the low and mid hanging fruit, and new ones are just increasingly difficult to find. The trouble is we don't invent these things, we have to discover them (we search for their use as natural defenses by plants and animals in the wild) and they can accurately be considered a finite resource.
Now in my opinion, out of all of the ways the modern world might come to an end, this is potentially the most likely, before wars or economic collapse or lack of drinking water. And the development of resistance to colistin is one of the final rings of the bell. I am typically not the pessimist but... this is kind of serious. understatement

One promising solution to this problem is to engineer other bacteria to kill super bugs. Antibiotics will be obsolete in the future and engineered viruses or bacteria will be used in their place. The power of bacteria far outweighs the power of antibiotics in the long run and are the only realistic solution once most feasible chemical permutations have been used up (barring a very expensive super antibiotic that's available to a certain few or those willing to go into massive debt). In short, the antibiotic resistance scare needn't frighten anyone because, in the end, we won't be using them to combat bacteria.

AMAZING Video! Complex as fuck issue described in 5 minutes if i try to explain it i ramble on for like 20 minutes. I have been warning about Antibiotic Resistance for 15 Years now. The answer that i heard the most was "Well then we get healthy naturally again...." My answer to that"Yeah you do that! Goodluck"  The other and MUCH bigger problem other then stupid people is that Making Antibiotics is not as easy as this video thinks it is. Yes new Antibiotics can be developed, but why would a company bankrupt themself on purpose? R&D for Antibiotics is quite hard, You want a compound that A can be Patented (one distinct molecule) easy to synthesize and of NO RISK to people taking it. Then you need to test. This testing will devour Insane amounts of money AGAIN. the whole process of developing and releasing a new antibiotic costs approx 3-10 BILLION USD (YES!) Impossible for a startup and unjustifiable for a Big company on the stockmarket. Since a new effective antibiotic will be as said before be classified as "Last resort" there is very little demand and thanks to expiring patents its just not making money. So thats why we are FUCKED...did i say we? Well, i have a neat lab where i can grow Phage rather easily. But that wont come to the mass marked either, because Phage therapy is a even bigger can of worms. So you are still FUCKED!

All the low hanging fruit has been plucked and we are entering back into the pre antibiotic era.

There's lots to be read on the topic if you search Google scholar for research papers.

It's also worth noting that the use of antibacterial consumer goods is a contributing factor. Research indicates that there is very little to no benefit to using antibacterial soaps and other consumer products (on average you would have to wash your hands 18 times a day for 30 each for it to affect bacterial populations on your hands). However the regular low level exposure contributes to the development of higher immunities in bacterial populations.
On top of that the antibacterial agent triclosan, commonly used in antibacterial consumer goods (including in some cases tooth paste), is found in most adults in the US (and is likely in adults in many areas of the developed world), and has been indicated as possibly contributing to issues in the endocrine system. Further it is not effectively removed from the sludge (aka biomass) retrieved from water treatment and used as fertilizer, as it is not required to be removed (in the US).

The underlying premise of this video is incorrect. Antibiotic resistant bacteria and DNA do not develop in response to the presence of antibiotics. That DNA didn't form via mutations in the presence of antibiotics. Those genes already existed through some other means. Here's an example of scientists finding antibiotic resistant bacteria in a cave isolated from the outside world for thousands of years, far before the development or use of antibiotics (or the development of humans who would create the antibiotics). http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/04/120411-drug-resistance-bacteria-caves-diseases-human-health-science/ There are other stories of finding resistant strains in isolated tribes and other areas there the bacteria could not have been in contact with the antibiotic they are resistant to.

Only by killing off those bacteria that are not resistant do the resistant populations gain enough of a population density to be dangerous (or noticed) on a large scale. But the individual bacteria did not create or gain a new ability due to the use of antibiotics. It's as silly as claiming that all dogs are white with black spots, PROVIDED, you kill all the dogs that are not dalmatians, and then claiming that white dogs with black spots are a new, and surprising development in dogs, never seen before!

There are effective ways to use normal antibiotics to counter these superbugs too! Increasing the concentration of the antibiotic to the point where the deactivation enzymes / pumps fail is possible with localized drug delivery (eg liposomes / micelles). I know I might be sounding like a broken record here, but maybe nanotechnology will help if we start running into dangerous territory with antibiotic resistance? If we keep on abusing antibiotics, accidentally breeding superbugs that're resistant to the vast majority, we might need to change up the game with a synthetic edge, using things that bacteria probably would be unable to cope with.

Rather than inhibiting their DNA replication or slowing down their metabolism, maybe one day we'll have "medicine" that actively rips hostile bacteria apart with nanoscopic steel mandibles, or jab them with stingers which administer a fatal (for bacteria) electrical shock, or even burrows into the bacterium and violently explodes. Sounds like sci-fi, but if we play our cards right we could have microscopic machines perfected to fill that particular niche where chemical medicine has to constantly evolve. Somehow I doubt bacteria could evolve to deal with the nano-equivalent of the Terminator, though hopefully the nano itself doesn't glitch as easily.

So the vast majority of antibiotic use is in Antibiotic Growth Promoters (AGPs) . These are added to animal feed well below the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) so resistance is much much less likely .  The purpose is to promote growth in a myriad of different ways, not necessarily due to "horrible living conditions" or to fight off disease. The reality is that prophylactic administration of clinically relevant antibiotics is relatively rare. That doesn't mean that livestock aren't a source of antibiotic resistance, at scale, even though clinical antibiotic use is relatively less frequent there are still a large number of animals that receive them; though their use is not as widespread as the video implies .  This is why most governments limit the use of antibiotics in livestock except as prescribed and administered by a veterinarian for a diagnosed disease.

There are a number of inaccuracies in the video. Implying that people take antibiotics to help a cold is wrong. Antibiotics require a prescription and a doctor won't give one for a cold because antibiotics don't kill viruses. Another false assertion is that worldwide travel can lead to a pandemic. On the contrary, the vast amount of travel and mixing of bacteria is crucial to preventing pandemics because it prevents bacteria and viruses from remaining in a single isolated host for a long duration. Travel done by the likes of Christopher Columbus did indeed cause the death of countless indigenous people but only because those people were not exposed to the bacteria and viruses before. Over time, the population on earth has been exposed to almost all kinds of parasites reducing the likelihood that a pandemic will ever occur.

Finally, gene editing and gene drives are solutions that can disable bacteria and viruses. The CRISPR CAS9 editing tool recently discovered in one of those solutions taking over the world.

The first line of defence should be bacteriophage therapy. It is cheap and easy to use, and has been in use in Russia for over 50 years. It is not a perfect cure, as bacteriophage is also attacked by the immune system while it fights the bacterial infection, and has limited results on internal organ infections.

A problem with the last bit in this video is that development of new antibiotic has essentially hit a stand still. Even if a new one is made with out toxic results to patients, a new super bug will just quickly emerge. Bacteriophage therapy avoids this because it is a living organism that changes with the bacteria.

There's also the fact that evolution isn't something like pokemon where the next form is strictly better than the previous. Organisms gain random mutations. Some help them and some don't. They can also lose random mutations, the loss of which can kill them or not.

Bacteriophages (basically viruses that attack bacteria) are a possible alternative to antibiotics and were used in the Soviet Union since they didn't have access to antibiotics. Although bacteria can become resistant to a specific bacteriophage, the bacteriophages can themselves mutate and attack the new super bug. The disadvantage is that bacteriophages only work against very specific strains of bacteria so a cocktail of bacteriophages are often administered at once. Although a new bacteriophage would have to be developed for every disease and for every time it mutated, there would always be a possible bacteriophage to deal with the bacteria. They also have other positives such as no side effects like some antibiotics.
I've heard an interesting idea regarding this issue. If we lose the antibiotics arms race, (which we probably will thanks to evolution,) then bacteriophages may be the next superweapon to turn to.

Thanks for another great video.  It's interesting you chose to focus on colistin.  Since it's a last-wall-of-defense type antibiotic, colistin is actually rarely used (at least in the US).  Therefore, the development of colistin resistance (which is interesting from a micro research standpoint) will directly result in a relatively small number of deaths.  A much bigger problem is actually fluoroquinolone (i.e. Cipro, Levaquin, etc...) resistance, since these drugs are used ubiquitously, and resistance is rising quickly.  It's probably >1000x more common to see a patient placed on a fluoroquinolone when they are infected with a fluroquinolone-resistant bacteria, than for a patient to be placed on colistin when they are infected with a colistin-resistant bacteria.
